overview: The subject examines the international debate on the nature and role of English in the world over the past 25 years. Issues of naming and variety are considered and the politics and economics of the spread of English is examined, as well as charges of linguistic imperialism, hegemony, and its impact on languages education more broadly including the teaching of other languages. Students need to demonstrate understanding of the issues presented and be able to assess a given context of English teaching with respect to the issues and propose ethical, linguistically and interculturally sound procedures for policy development and teaching practices.
intended learning outcomes: Critically appraise and explain the application of current methodologies for an additional language context
Critique and manage language curricular and resources which are culturally and linguistically appropriate
Interpret and apply advanced professional knowledge of key areas of specialisation for an additional language context

assessments.description: Tasks completed in class and online on teaching curricular/resources (one mid semester and one late in the semester). 1000 words (total)
Essay on the nature of English as an international language. 1750 words
Essay on the impact of English as an international language on teaching methodologies and approaches. 2250 words
Hurdle requirement:. Minimum 80% attendance at all tutorials, seminars and workshops.

Semester 1.Contact hours: 24 hours (16 hours of on campus classes and 8 hours of asynchronous activities)

Prescribed texts: McKay, S. L. (2002). Teaching English as an international language: Rethinking goals and approaches. Oxford, England, Oxford University Press.
